It is a common misconception that water is H2O. That is true only for de-ionised water. Water that you get out of the tap is largely H3O because an extra proton (which is Hydrogen without the electron) is loosely bound to the slightly negatively charged H2O molecule. It is slightly negative due to the way the electrons are shared and orbit around the H2O molecule.

Dihydrogen monoxide:

is called "hydroxyl acid", the substance is the major component of acid rain.
contributes to the "greenhouse effect".
may cause severe burns.
is fatal if inhaled.
contributes to the erosion of our natural landscape.
accelerates corrosion and rusting of many metals.
may cause electrical failures and decreased effectiveness of automobile brakes.
has been found in excised tumors of terminal cancer patients.

Despite the danger, dihydrogen monoxide is often used:

as an industrial solvent and coolant.
in nuclear power plants.
in the production of Styrofoam.
as a fire retardant.
in many forms of cruel animal research.
in the distribution of pesticides. Even after washing, product remains contaminated by this chemical.
as an additive in certain "junk-foods" and other food products.
The average composition of water is primarily H2O but also D2O, T2O, H2O(17), H2O(18) and HDO. Also, let's not forget the fact that water slightly dissociates into H3O+ and OH- ions.

well if you took a 2nd year this would make much more sense.  What's happening is water can act as an acid and a base, so it can actually react with itself.  In that reaction, a proton shifts from one water molecule to another (a proton is a hydrogen atom without any electrons).  One is Hydroxide, the other is Hydronium.  Both are crucial to acidity.  If neither existed in water, the pH wouldn't be measurable (at least to my current understanding)

So... that's hydroxide ions and WHAT ions? XD

Well for most measurements, I don't think the OH and H3O will make a difference.   For instance, something simple like a reaction.  As the water reacts with something, the OH and H3O would turn to water to maintain a set ratio of OH and H3O to water.  This means it doesn't matter that there is OH and H3O in the water in many measurements.  We wouldn't be able to measure the pH of water if there was no H3O in it, so it is important, however for measurements it can be pretty much ignored.
I think that draws up a question. Is the video talking about it conceptually or realistically? Because when taking measurements with water, scientists discount any discrepancies of OH- and H3O+.

well H3O+ and OH- aren't exactly ions of water.  An ion is formed when an electron is attached to or removed from an atom.  In this case, a bare proton attaches or is removed from a water molecule.  (a bare proton is just hydrogen without any electrons around it)

H3O is what determines pH.  If you have a lot of H3O, your pH is very low.  If you had a cup of HCl mixed with water (which it usually is), you'd actually end up with a bunch of H3O and Cl rather than HCl.  OH is the opposite.

water can act as both an acid and a base, which means it can react with itself to form hydroxide (OH-) and hydronium(H30+).

As far as I'm aware, that's just the way it is.  I'm not sure exactly how a cup of water knows how much Hydronium and Hydroxide to make, but I'd assume it probably has something to do with energy.

Well, to my limited understanding of chemistry: ions are still the same compound - they're just, well, ions. Kind of like different isotopes of an element are still that element. A gold ion is still a gold atom.

So water ions are still water. 

Like I said, my chemistry is reeeeally basic, so I'm just chatting out my personal thoughts here.
is there an answer to why water equilibrates like that?

well, in a way you're right, but for the case of water, that doesn't quite work.  Because water can be both an acid and a base, it will react with itself with the equation:  H2O + H2O = OH- + H3O+ (you're supposed to have a double sided arrow for reactions like that, but youtube wont let me)

at equilibrium, a cup of water is only mostly water.  Small parts of it are hydroxide and hydronium ions, which are pretty much impossible to remove because as soon as you remove them, more are created.

It has to do with water's equilibrium constant.  The constant is 1E-14, which is equal to the concentration of H3O * the concentration of OH

If you change the system, it will try to return to that eq value.  So if a H30 and OH combine to form water, then as a result, two water molecules will react with each other to replace the loss of the H3O and OH.

Exactly, but you don't seem to get my point, my point is that you can have a banced formula that ends up with 3 molecules of water, this is when you get a reaction between a single molecule of ozone (O3), against 3 molecules of Hydrogen gas (3(H2)). in short 3(H2)+O3=3(H2O). There are other formulas where you end up with a different amount of water molecule plus something else example in respiration, you start with 1 glucose and 6 oxygen, and end up with 6 CO2 and 6 water, still balanced .

you only balance chemical formulae when you have an actual reaction (2+ reactants and 1+ products) that have an unequal number of atoms on either side (conservation of mass, matter etc). What's all this discussion about how to balance water all 3(H2o) means is that you have three moles of water molecules.

Molecules ACTUALLY COLLIDING (to keep it simple).  If they have enough speed they will actually rip themselves apart. Then, they will ACTUALLY COLLIDE again. They will make new bonds. (Yeah, crazy. I know.)

Something has to cause that release. And, how is water stored in space? I doubt that oxygen and hydrogen molecules just float by a planet and decide that it needs water, and do their bonding thing just for that purpose.

And what is the mechanism for breaking and reforming those bonds? "Lightening strike"? Really? How do you get hydrogen to exothermically react with oxygen? In a vacuum? Wouldn't a molten hot planet defeat the possibility of liquid water?
There is no energy being created or destroyed.  It is simply being released from the system.

There is inherent energy in the bonds in H2 and O2. The energy in them comes from when they were formed (Hydrogen being one of the "primordial" elements formed in the big bang, and Oxygen being formed in stars.  When you break those bonds, and reform them into the bonds that "hold together" H2O, there is excess energy.  It is what is known as an "exothermic reaction."  Yes, there has to be an ignition point (whether that be a molten hot planet, or a lightning strike, it doesn't really matter.)

Fire= fuel, oxygen, and heat, all three must be present for combustion. Fuel and oxygen are potential energy, not useful energy.
So, fuel and oxygen = water, which is the product of a reaction that isn't created yet? or energy that isn't created yet? Remember the first law of thermodynamics? Energy doesn't transform from fuel and oxygen.

Hydrogen combusts to FORM water. In the process it releases a bunch of energy. That energy is already contained the in the bonds of the molecules of H2 and O2.  It is just that H2O has less energy in its bonds, so the energy escapes as heat.

Also, fuel+oxygen DOES equal Energy(fire) (as well as H2O).  It is just that it isn't "created." It is just a product of the reaction, just as the H2O isn't "created," just a product of the reaction.
Thank you.

@joebananatube basically a dipole is a molecule that has a positive end and a negative end. and kind of works as a magnet. Basically these water molecules are attracted to each other due to this dipole property. Now, they don't act like magnets in the sense that they stick perfectly together. They are just more attracted to each other. Oxygen however, it doesnt have this dipole property and doesnt have any intermolecular forces acting on it, at least not strong ones.

@joebananatube @joebananatube and what you produce is water vapour. Now to answer your second question. I'm assuming you mean why is water liquid at room temperature when it has oxygen, yet liquid oxygen is gas at room temperature. This has to do with the molecular interactions between the atoms. Basically, there are forces that occur at the atomic level, and these forces determine the physical properties of the substances. Water molecules have this property called a dipole.

@joebananatube and what you produce is water vapour. Now to answer your second question. I'm assuming you mean why is water liquid at room temperature when it has oxygen, yet liquid oxygen is gas at room temperature. This has to do with the molecular interactions between the atoms. @joebananatube to answer your question about 2 gases becoming a liquid, you have to first understand this. If you took pure oxygen gas and pure hydrogen gas, put them in a tank together, they wouldnt just make water. To cause these 2 gases to form water, you need to give the gas molecules enough energy to make the water. So, this means that you need to apply an external form of energy such as heat. This is basically how hydrogen fuel cells work, you apply a heat to hydrogen gas and oxygen gas
